block.p: WHAT'S NEXT, A STUDEBAKER? An automaker in China is bringing back the British MG sports car, part of a trend in which Chinese companies are buying troubled foreign brands and remaking them as their own. [Page C1.]

RETHINKING SARBANES-OXLEY Top Bush administration officials are beginning discussions with corporate executives and accounting firms about rolling back post-Enron reforms and limiting liability from government and shareholder lawsuits. Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., above, said he hoped that the talks would lead to regulatory changes in the months ahead. [C1.]
QUESTIONING HALLIBURTON Congressional Democrats are questioning the Halliburton Company's plan to relocate its chief executive to Dubai. [C1.]
LEARNING TO LOBBY Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York recently had a dinner and a strong message for the billionaires running some of the top hedge funds in the country. [C1.]

A LENDER'S DECLINE Wall Street once welcomed New Century Financial with open arms and credit lines worth billions of dollars. Now it has shut off the spigot, and New Century is seeking a white knight. [C1.]
MISSISSIPPI STRIKE Nearly 7,000 workers on strike at the giant Ingalls Shipyard in Mississippi are demanding better wages and benefits in the wake of post-Katrina price increases. [A13.]
GUIDELINES BUT NO ANSWERS The Food and Drug Administration offered guidelines on fresh-cut produce, but it cannot say what caused outbreaks connected to E. coli and salmonella. [A17.]
NEW CELLPHONE STORES AT&T is opening 11 new retail stores, the first in Houston, that are intended to make buying a cellphone less difficult and more enjoyable. [C3.]
ALFALFA SALES HALTED A federal judge has stopped the sale of Monsanto's genetically engineered alfalfa seed. [C3.]
AKZO NOBEL UNIT SOLD The Schering-Plough Corporation will buy the Organon BioSciences unit of Akzo Nobel for $14.4 billion in cash. [C7.]
ALMOST A RECORD In a mild surprise, China's trade surplus for February has nearly equaled last October's record of $23.76 billion. [C3.]
FIRST MOVIES, NOW FASHION The Weinstein Company has acquired Halston, the legendary fashion brand, in partnership with a private equity firm. [C7.]
EQUITY FIRM BUYS RETAILER The giant buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is purchasing the discount retailer Dollar General and taking it private. [C3.]
NO COUNT A compromise by television networks and advertising companies for measuring how many people watch TV commercials has hit a snag. Advertising. [C8.]
ASTON MARTIN SOLD Ford Motor has sold its Aston Martin division to a group including a former British racecar driver. [C2.]
A PRODUCTIVITY ENHANCER A study says money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity. [C4.]

DEVICE MAKER PONDERS I.P.O. Boston Scientific is considering a public stock offering of its endosurgery businesses, which could raise $1 billion to help it pay off debts from its purchase of a rival device maker, Guidant, last year. If completed, the offering would be the biggest in the medical device business since 2002. [C2]

CHARGES OF FRAUD Regulators in the United States and Canada filed civil charges against former executives of Nortel Networks, a large maker of telecommunications equipment, accusing them of committing accounting fraud. [C2.]
NICE REWARD IF YOU CAN GET IT The all-expenses employer-paid trip to reward workers is back, with a twist. Itineraries. [C9.]
DEFENDING CLEAR Steven Brill, the man behind a registered travel program Clear, answered some tough questions about the company. On the Road: Joe Sharkey [C9.]
ONLINE

ALL ABOUT EXECUTIVE PAY Bristol-Myers accepted a proposal that its chief executive's pay be subject to approval by three-quarters of its independent directors. The chief executive at Boston Scientific got only 35 percent of his bonus for 2006.
